org.orgName: District Court of the United States

div1.p: UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON NORTHERN DIVISION.
In the Matter of the Application of MAC FOCK for a Writ of Habeas Corpus.

Now comes the petitioner, through the undersigned Counsel, and answering the return to the Writ of Habeas Corpus heretofore granted herein, and particularly the affirmative return to said Writ, found on pages III and IV, alleges:
I

That he denies each and every allegation contained on page 3 of said affirmative return to said Writ, except that he., the said Ellis DeBruler, as Commissioner of Immigration aforesaid, holds the said Mac Fock under an order of deportation to the Republic of China, from which he came to the United States, arriving at the Port of Seattle on the Steamship Ixion on the 14th day of April, 1913; that said Mac Fock, upon his arrival on said port of Seattle, applied for admission into the United States as a returning native born American of Chinese descent, and that there upon a hearing was had before the respondent as Commissioner of Immigration, upon evidence both oral and documentary, duly offered in said matter, and that said documentary evidence includes a certain certificate then in the possesion of the said Mac Fock, the original of which constitutes a part of the original record of the hearing of said Mac Fock before the Bureau of Immigration and the Department of Labor.
AND FOR A FURTHER AFFIRMATIVE REPLY to said affirmative return to said Writ, your petitioner alleges:
I

That for fifteen (15) years, your petitioner remained in the United States, living in various Eastern cities, after obtaining the decree of the United States Commissioner set forth
in his petition herein. That early in the year 1900, he returned to China via the port of Seattle, and previous to his departure, presented his certificate of discharge to the local immigration commissioner, asking for a pre-investigation of his status. The local commissioner at that time communicated with the Department in Boston as to the genuineness of the petitioner's discharge, and was informed by the Department of Boston that said discharge was genuine, and that your petitioner was the rightful holder thereof, all of which may be verified by a letter from the Boston Department under date of April 30, which is on file in this case. That during the month of April of the present year, the petitioner returned to this country via the Port of Seattle, and on March 22, was examined by the local inspectors. That under the rules and regulations of the immigration department, and particularly rule 4 and 24, the officer conducts a private examination with on the witnesses present whom he may designate; that this petitioner had no Counsel, and no one to warn him or tell him what his rights in the premises were, and under said rule, even if he had been able to procure one, his Counsel is only permitted to look at the testimony, but to take no part in the proceedings; that no provision was made for summoning witnesses from a distance, or for taking depositions, and he was tried in a way that in law and fact amounted to force and duress and abuse of discretion on the part of the immigration department, particularly in view of the decision of the United States Commissioner heretofore set forth in the petition herein, and take through a star chamber proceeding of the most un-American sort, and never warned that by speaking frankly and fairly to the Immigration officers, he was possibly depriving himself of his constitutional rights, and that all said rules and regulations of said Department are calculated to amount to confessions from an immigrant and to compel him against his will to make statements which in fact are not true, which was the case of this petitioner and this petitioner is informed and believes and so states the
fact to be, that all oral testimony, including the statement of this petitioner, under them, as alleged in the affirmative return of the respondent, that he was born in China, is evidence that should not and cannot in a Writ of Habeas Corpus proceeding, be used against him, but only the record evidence, according to the constitution of the United States in such case made and provided.
WHEREFORE, your petitioner prays to be dismissed as in his original petitioner set forth.
L. Frank Brown
Victor M. Place
Attorneys for Petitioner.
STATE OF WASHINGTON COUNTY OF K I N G
}}} ss
UNITED STATES OF AMERICA WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON
:: ss

L. Frank Brown, being duly sworn on oath, deposes and says: that he is one of the Counsel in this cause, duly authorized to act for the petitioner, and is familiar with the facts, and that to the best of his knowledge, information and belief, the facts herein stated are true.
L. Frank Brown
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 21st day of August, 1913.
Phillip Tindall
Notary Public in and for the State of Washington, residing at Seattle.
